Award.AwardTitle: American-Russian Investigation of the NEVA Wreck and Survivors? Camp: 200th Anniversary Expedition, Sitka, Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration: The PIs propose a 3-year underwater archaeological investigation for the wreck of the Russian American Company frigate Neva, and the excavation of a site where possibly 26 survivors waited for rescue for 24 days in 1813. The proposed project would support three-years of collaborative research among Untied States and Russian scholars to investigate the shipwreck of the Neva, which was wrecked off Kruzoff Island near Sitka in January 1813 and a site on the adjacent mainland which is believed to have been the 1813 survivor's camp. The research coincides with the two hundred year anniversary of the shipwreck. The research will include underwater reconnaissance and archaeology at the purported shipwreck site, archaeological excavation at the survivor's camp, archival research, interviews, metallurgical, faunal analysis, XRF of glass artifacts, and public education. The applicants point out that the Neva is one of the most important ships in the history of Russian America because it was used in the first Russian voyage around the world and was engaged to retake Sitka from the Tlingit Tribes in 1804.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Russian sailing ship Neva left Siberia for what is present day Sitka, Alaska, in late August 1812 with around 77 crew and passengers. Due to the lateness of the sailing season and a series of unfortunate events, she never made it. Constructed in 1800, the Neva was the first Russian ship (along with a sister ship, the Nedezhda) to engage in a round the world voyage during 1803-1806.  She was also the first Russian ship to visit Hawaii and Australia. To Alaskans the ship is best known as the deciding force in the Battle of Sitka, in which Russian fur hunters drove the Sitka Tlingit out of their homeland – allowing the Russians to establish a stronghold at a place called Castle Hill in Sitka. To the Tlingit, the Neva is an unwelcome reminder of the conflict – even though a belated peace between the Sitka Tlingit and Russia was ceremonially proclaimed in 2004.

A collaborative 2012 archaeological survey by the Alaska Office of History and Archaeology, the U.S. Forest Service, and the Sitka Historical Society identified a site (SIT-963) believed to be the camp of survivors from the January 1813 wreck of the Russian-American Company ship NEVA.  During 2015-2016, an international team of archaeologists from the U.S., Canada, and Russia conducted excavations at the site with support from the National Science Foundation (Award No. PLR-1330939). Because the survival camp is in Tongass National Forest, upland work was conducted under USDA Forest Service Archaeological Resources Protection Act (ARPA) permits (ID No. SIT699/620935010602 and ID No. SIT712/62093501062). Concurrent research was conducted on State submerged and intertidal lands adjacent to the Tongass under an Alaska Office of History and Archaeology permit (No. 2014-02, as amended). This allowed for offshore remote sensing by marine magnetometer and sidescan sonar, as well as scuba surveys. The excavations at SIT-963 revealed artifacts believed to be associated with the 1813 survival camp, including gunflints, part of a nautical divider, a brass buckle, lead shot, cannon trunnion caps, a wrought drift pin, copper sheathing, a scabbard finial, and nails of copper and iron. Some of the ship’s debris, such as lead shot and copper sheathing, had been modified for use in a survival situation. In an area believed to be in the trajectory of flotsam from the wreck, the team discovered cached materials that included copper sheathing, axes, iron bar stock, and hardware from a cannon carriage. A grave with the outline of a hastily constructed coffin was discovered at the edge of the survivor camp area but was not excavated. While intrusive materials from a nearby mid-to-late 19th century hunting camp were present, the overall picture is one of improvisation and survival. Faunal analysis indicated that the survivors were able to harvest Sitka deer and other resources from the land and sea.

The results of the field investigation, along with archival research in St. Petersburg and London, have added details to our knowledge of the NEVA’s history and of the archaeology of survival in a harsh environment. The NEVA survivor camp has provided a snapshot in time for January 1813, contributing to our understanding of supply in Russian America. More importantly it has provided a rare material record of human behavior in a crisis, and insights into the adaptations that allowed the wreck survivors to await rescue. The study has replaced some of the “lore of the sea” with scientific outcomes.
